results.title: Qesa: stories from the Craig Family Centre
results.brief_description: The African nation of Sudan has suffered the longest periods of sustained civil war in history. In this compilation of digital stories, women from North and South Sudan recount their experience of war, migration and settlement in Australia.

results.title: Picture books on video. - Volume 2 = Turramulli and the giant Quinkin
results.creator_credit: Catharine Campbell, Cathy Miller and Video Classroom
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal Dreamtime stories. “Turramulli the giant Quinkin” and “Banana Bird and the Snake men” are both written by Percy Trezise, illustrated by Dick Roughsey and narrated by Bob Maza. “The Frog and the pelican” is written by Des O’Brien. The stories are narrated with background music as the illustrations are shown on screen.
results.title_for_label: Picture books on video. - Volume 2 = Turramulli and the giant Quinkin
results.creator_credit_for_label: Catharine Campbell, Cathy Miller and Video Classroom

The stories are narrated with background music as the illustrations are shown on screen.

The stories are narrated with background music as the illustrations are shown on screen.

results.title: Darwin's body snatchers
results.creator_credit: Chris Oxley, Channel 4, U K and Laurel Productions
results.brief_description: This program looks at the export trade in Aboriginal skeletons, skulls and body parts rife during the nineteenth century and which continued up until 1940. Anthropologists and museums influenced by the work of Charles Darwin sought these remains for scientific study and museum exhibition. Australian doctors, scientists and supposedly respectable citizens may have colluded in both grave robbing and “killing to order”, to fulfil the European demand for the supply of Aboriginal bodies, which were treated as commodities. The program looks at shifts in museum policy and the efforts by groups such as the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre to have these remains repatriated from overseas institutions back to Australia for proper burial by their descendants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chris Oxley, Channel 4, U K and Laurel Productions

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 09
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. Andrew MacKenzie in this episode introduces the annual Experimenta exhibition held at Southgate, ‘Prototype’. Artists in the exhibition include: Stephen Barras (Op Shop), Richard Brown (Mimetic Starfish), Jane Crappsley, Chris Henschke, Isobel Knowles, Hama Marriott, Ben Morieson (Burnout 2001 - Part 1 - The game), Iain Mott, Marc Raszewski, Jim Sosnin, Bruce Mowson (Flesh Antenna), Simon Morton, Martin Walch, Amy Youngs, Christopher Mether, Elizabeth Vander Zaag. Screen Talk looks at the video work of Kate Just who discusses her motivations, comic relief and the spontaneous nature of her work. Excerpts of video work include: ‘Home alone’, ‘Marsha’, ‘Needle exchange’ and ‘Beat bag baby’.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 2. Ep. 11
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program (now in its second series) produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew MacKenzie along with co-presenter Lena Corner, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew MacKenzie deviates from the program’s usual format to incorporate an in-depth interview with English artist, art critic, writer and television producer, Matthew Collings on the eve of his Australian lecture tour, 2002. Collings provides a refreshing and challenging outlook on contemporary art and provides contextual observation on contemporary art values and practice. Collings is best known for the BBC series ‘This is Modern Art’ and his book ‘Crazy Nation’ amongst others. Screen Talk this week looks at the work of Geneine Honey and includes an interview with excerpts from ‘Young Sad Love’ and ‘Don’t Go Out Walking’.

results.title: Australian women's heritage: 1945-1986
results.brief_description: This program starts with the post-war baby boom and goes on to look at immigration, housing, views on women’s work, the rock and roll craze and the new morality, the pill, censorship and equal pay - all issues highly relevant to Australian women in this era. Issues important to Aboriginal women are also explored. Some individual women highlighted in this episode are Germaine Greer, Bobbie Sykes, Kath Walker, Dawn Fraser, Dame Joan Sutherland, Jan Marsh, Judith Wright and Pat O’Shane.
